subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 12 October 2018: Stocks stabilise after rout
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, crude up, dollar up.
* REAR-VIEW: Mnuchin upbeat on US economy, US Banks kick off earnings season, Fed's Evans urges neutral policy stance, UK and EU reportedly to discuss extension of Brexit transition, IEA Monthly Oil Report boost in oil output and cut demand growth forecast, BoE Haldane sees gradual hikes, Turkey releases Pastor Brunson, Uni of Mich soft.
* NEXT WEEK: FOMC and RBA Minutes, Italian Budget Submission Deadline, Earnings season begins, US Retail Sales, New Zealand CPI, UK Labour Market Data, Chinese CPI, US Industrial Production, UK CPI, EZ CPI, FPC Minutes, Labour Market Data, UK Retail Sales, Chinese GDP, Japanese CPI, Canadian CPI.

* TREASURY SECRETARY MNUCHIN said he could not be happier with the performance of the US economy, noting that a market correction is natural. He believes the market is digesting higher treasury supply quite well noting there is a ‘lot of demand’ for US bonds; he expects the yield curve to normalise. On trade, he noted the President is right when he says that tariffs are an important negotiating tool and reiterated the possibility of a meeting with Chinese president Xi at the G20. He once again urged a reciprocal relationship with China and reported to have had productive discussions with PBoC Governor where he expressed concerns over Yuan weakness. He added that opening its market would be good for the Chinese economy and stressed that ‘whatever we make on trade we do not want to lose in currencies’. Finally, he thinks a trade deal with EU is possible before a deal with China since the EU is ready and China is not. Elsewhere, he stressed that Trump respects the independence of the Fed.

* FED: Fed's Evans (non-voter, dove) said it is time to re-adjust policy stance to neutral, stipulating that a 'restrictive' Fed policy may mean 50bps above neutral. On the US economy he noted growth is above trend, he sees unemployment falling to 3.5% before it eases back up a little bit and thinks inflation is not a concern, therefore a slightly restrictive policy makes sense. Alluding to Trump’s recent criticism, Evans noted that the questioning of rate hikes is fair.

* BREXIT: A UK PM May Spokesperson said UK PM May will never agree to a Brexit backstop plan that will trap Britain in a customs union permanently, stressing the backstop must be temporary; in response, DUP's Deputy Leader Dodds said it is critical that Brexit backstop is time limited. The spokesperson added that big issues remain in focus ahead of next week’s EU summit; EU Brexit negotiator Barnier also said ‘we continue our constant dialogue with EU27 member states on Brexit deal’. Separately, Business Insider reported that UK PM May has been given until Monday to change her Brexit plan or suffer Cabinet walkouts. EU Diplomatic sources have said that the UK and EU are to discuss extending the Brexit transition phase; this followed from earlier Buzzfeed reports suggesting UK Brexit Minister Raab feels he cannot endorse a Brexit deal without a set time limit on membership of a customs union citing November 27th as the commons vote date. The reports also suggested several UK cabinet ministers have discussed the possibility of extending the implementation period by 6 months to avoid a backstop whilst one senior Tory Remain MP was said to have discussed with colleagues the possibility of voting down the deal, so there can be two more referendums. The article also stated that a Eurosceptic lawmaker has produced a list of 25 Tory rebels who will vote down Chequers. EU official says Brexit talks are making progress, but there is no deal yet; talks to continue over the weekend, and there will be an evaluation on Sunday evening; EU and UK will announce progress on Monday.

* BOE: BoE's Haldane believes that the markets’ forecast of 25bps a year in the base rate is not 'dissimilar' to the MPC's forecasts for pay growth; he expects 'limited and gradual' increase in wage growth which will be underpin limited and gradual increases in interest rates.

* ITALY: Economy Minister Tria has met with EU's Economic and Financial Affairs Commissioner Moscovici on Friday and the dialogue was said to be 'constructive'. Earlier, EU President Juncker expressed once again criticism over Italy’s plan stating the country is not keeping its word on the budget. Elsewhere, Italian Minister for South Lezzi said the government will monitor budget targets every 3 months and will intervene if the numbers do not correspond with plans; he added that there is no obligation for state-controlled companies to make additional investments.

* UNI OF MICHIGAN sentiment index saw a slight drop to 99 from 100.1 and missed expectations at 100.4. Analysts at Pantheon note the print was pushed down by expectations and current conditions components even though they remain elevated consistent with a spending growth of 4%-12%. They warn however that the pace cannot be sustained as real income growth is now at less than 3% and, given the headline’s sensitiveness to the stock market, if the recent drop in stocks is sustained confidence could ‘take a hit in the next month or two’.

* SPX +1.4% at 2768, NDX +2.8% at 7160, DJI +1.2% at 25335. SECTORS: Energy +0.4%, Materials +0.5%, Industrials +0.6%, Cons Discretionary +2.2%, Cons Staples +0.6%, Healthcare +1.5%, Financials +0.2%, Tech +3.2%, Telecoms +2.2%, Utilities +0.1%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Several heavyweight banks reported earnings on Friday, with Citi (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) up on the day, whilst JPMorgan (JPM) and PNC Financial (PNC) underperformed. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) was a top mover after promising reviews of its new Call of Duty franchise. Netflix (NFLX) moved higher on the back of an upgrade at Citi. Intuit (INTU) was another gainer as was the technology sector as a whole. Johnson Controls International (JCI) was a bottom mover, mimicking poor performance from the wider utilities sector. Alongside PNC Financial (PNC), other regional banks Regions Financial (RF) and US Bancorp (USB) were down on the day. Estee Lauder (EL) also pushed lower after a downgrade at JPMorgan.

* WTI (X8) SETTLES USD $0.37 AT $71.4/BBL. It's a red week for Brent and WTI, and there was further pressure on the crude complex on Friday after the IEA's monthly report saw the organisation revise down oil demand in 2018 and 2019, while also reporting a 100k BPD rise in OPEC production; additionally, the IEA reported OECD stocks at the highest levels since February. Elsewhere, on Friday Baker Hughes reported US oil rigs rose 8 in the week (GoM rigs were unchanged), gas rigs were up 4, and total rigs were up 11.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE 1+ TICKS LOWER AT 118-11. Treasuries started the session negative amid a more constructive risk environment, where equities stabilised after the recent rout. The net result was that the T-Note traded within Thursday’s range. There were upticks after a soft Uni of Michigan sentiment survey, and the complex  firmed towards the close after equities suffered a little wobble. Some desks were noting that dealers sold into the upswing. Major spreads were uneventful.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP: USD: The Dollar is ending a tough and roller-coaster week softer, but off worst levels as a key Fib level just below the 95.000 handle continues to hold. However, having registered a peak just above last week’s high around 96.134 it has been mainly one-way trade lower amidst benign inflation data (PPI and CPI), a Wednesday-Thursday Wall Street meltdown and latest berating for the FOMC by President Trump for tightening policy too much and quickly.

* GBP, EUR:  Very volatile moves in the Pound and single currency, but both currently nearer the top than bottom of 1.1430-1.1610 and 1.3025-1.3260-ranges vs the Usd circa 1.3180 and 1.1550. The Eur has been undermined by ongoing Italian budget conflict as Rome’s coalition Government remains resolute and the EU insists that the regime is not sticking to the rules or its word, according to Juncker. Note, official presentation is due on Monday and the response after deliberation, but it appears that Brussels will deem that at least the 2019 plan violates the rules. Meanwhile, following positive reports from both side on progress towards a Brexit agreement, and some talk that the deed or deal could be done as soon as next Monday, divisions within PM May’s Tory party, parliament and between the UK and EU persist, and over key issues, like the Irish border, customs union and indeterminant length of back-stop.

*JPY: A net safe-haven gainer vs the Usd within 111.80-113.95 trading parameters on the wide amidst all the ongoing global trade rifts and extended YUAN depreciation after China’s return from Golden Week and latest RRR cut that did not protect on or offshore stocks from a mid-week slump.

* CHF: In stark contrast to the Jpy, and even Gold that reclaimed some of its attraction in times of pronounced risk aversion, the Franc has weakened vs the Greenback between a 0.9855-0.9955 band, and from 1.1365 to almost 1.1500 against the Eur for no apparent or clear fundamental reason in terms of Swiss specifics. Hence, the implication and word in markets has been some kind of ‘official’ intervention.

* AUD, NZD, CAD: The antipodean Dollars are both holding the bulk of their recovery gains vs the Usd, but not before falling to fresh multi-month lows circa 0.7040 and 0.6420 respectively. Some encouraging Aussie and NZ macro impulses have aided the rebound alongside the relatively soft Greenback with the aud back above 0.7100 and Kiwi hovering just over 0.6500, but underperforming with the cross close to 1.0950. Meanwhile, the Loonie is pretty mid-range vs its US counterpart having hit highs circa 1.2920 vs 1.3070 lows amidst broadly weak Canadian housing data, and not straying far from a decent 1 bn option expiry at the 1.3000 strike.

* NOK, SEK: Strong performances for both Scandi crowns that were inflated by above consensus Norwegian and Swedish CPI reports (headline and core) that will keep the Norges Bank and Riksbank firmly in tightening gear. On that note, December rate hike odds in Sweden increased and Skingsely said NIRP could be unwound during the course of next year. To recap, latest guidance is for a rate hike at the end of 2018 or in February next year.

* EM: Mostly positive weeks for regional currencies, with the Brl carrying a decent post-Brazilian election result round 1 bid until front-runner for the run off vote Bolsanaro’s choice for Finance Minister became the subject of fraud investigations. However, the Try is still maintaining gains above 6.0000 vs the Usd after an extremely whippy Friday session and the release of US Pastor Brunson that compounded bullish moves on a bigger than anticipated Turkish current account surplus and more Government initiatives designed to try and bring CPI back down towards target.

* COMING-UP: Monday - US Retail Sales, New Zealand CPI, Italian Budget Submission Deadline Tuesday - UK Labour Market Data, Chinese CPI, RBA Minutes, US Industrial Production, Earnings from IBM, Johnson & Johnson, Morgan Stanley, Blackrock, Netflix & Goldman Sachs Wednesday - UK CPI, EZ CPI, FPC Minutes, FOMC Minutes Thursday - Australian Labour Market Data, UK Retail Sales, Earnings from Unilever, American Express, Paypal, Philip Morris & Novartis Friday - Chinese GDP, Japanese CPI, Canadian CPI, Earnings from P&G. For the full RANsquawk week In Focus report click here.

* CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY - Previewing FOMC minutes, RBA minutes, BOC outlook survey, Banxico minutes, NBH meeting; reviewing ECB minutes.  For the full RANsquawk week Central Bank Weekly report click here.

RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 12th October 2018 - Earnings from C, JPM, PNC, WFC
content:

If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Earnings from Citigroup Inc (C), JPMorgan Chase & Co (JPM), PNC Financial Services Group Inc (PNC), Wells Fargo & Co (WFC)
  • Netflix (NFLX) upgraded to Buy from Neutral at Citigroup
  • Activision Blizzard (ATVI) – Baird says initial reviews for Call of Duty are positive.

12th October 2018

EARNINGS

  • Citigroup Inc (C) Q3 EPS USD 1.73 vs. Exp. USD 1.69, revenue USD 18.4bln vs. Exp. USD 18.45bln. Q3 fixed income markets revenue USD 3.2bln vs. Exp USD 2.95bln. Q3 operating expenses USD 10.3bln. (Newswires)
  • JPMorgan Chase & Co (JPM) Q3 EPS USD 2.34 vs. Exp. USD 2.25, revenue USD 27.3bln vs. Exp. USD 27.5bln. Net Interest Income +7% USD 14.1bln. FICC sales and Trading Revenue USD 2.84bln vs. Exp USD 2.96bln. Q3 Investment Banking Revenue USD 1.73bln vs. Exp USD 1.82bln. Sees FY18 net interest income USD 55.5bln+/-. (Newswires)
  • PNC Financial Services Group Inc (PNC) Q3 EPS USD 2.82 vs. Exp. USD 2.72, revenue USD 4.4bln vs. Exp. USD 4.35bln. Sees Q4 net interest income up low-single digits. (Newswires)
  • Wells Fargo & Co (WFC) Q3 EPS USD 1.13 vs. Exp. USD 1.17, revenue USD 21.9bln vs. Exp. USD 21.9bln. Residential Mortgage Loan Originations USD 46bln vs. prev. USD 50bln. Mortgage Banking Income USD 846mln vs. prev. USD 770mln. Q3 noninterest expense USD 13.8bln. Reports allowance for credit losses USD 11bln at September 30th.  (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Boeing (BA) – Airbus (AIR FP) could beat Boeing to the market for a long-range narrow body jet, which could hit the market by 2023. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – A new expose book, "Noncompliant: A Lone Whistleblower Exposes the Giants of Wall Street" by Carmen Segarra, claims that the incoming CEO, David Solomon, once dismissed criticism of the co. double-dealing in an energy merger as a matter of “perception”. (Newswires)
  • Intel (INTC) – The chip maker has reduced its stake in its Netherlands-based supplier ASML (ASML) to under 3%. (Newswires)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The pharma products co. has been cleared of liability in a case made against it by a woman claiming its talc-based products contains asbestos and gave her cancer. (Newswires)
  • Verizon (VZ) – The telecom co., who previously told 1,000 departing workers there would be no severance package when they move to Infosys (INFY), is now offering the alternative to take an exit package instead of moving to Infosys. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • AbbVie (ABBV) – The pharmaceutical announced a global resolution with Novartis (NVS) over an IP litigation over Novartis’ proposed biosimilar adalimumab product. (Newswires)
  • Activision Blizzard (ATVI) – Baird says initial reviews for Call of Duty are positive. (Newswires)
  • Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) – The pharmaceutical announced its Phase 3 checkmate-331 does not meet its primary end point of overall survival with Opdivo vs. chemotherapy in patients previously treated for small-cell lung cancer. (Newswires)
  • Duke Energy (DUK) – The energy co. is assessing the damage done in the Florida Panhandle from Hurricane Michael, where an estimated 31,000 customers lost power. (Newswires)
  • Eli Lilly (LLY) – The pharma co. has launched a Thriver Movement for patients with metastatic breast cancer, to improve resources available for patients. (Newswires)
  • Estee Lauder (EL) – The cosmetics co. is suing Deciem after its founder, Brandon Truaxe, moved to shut down the co.’s stores claiming the co. engaged in “criminal activity”. (WSJ)
  • Starbucks (SBUX) – The coffee maker announced an accelerates USD 5bln share buyback. (Newswires) 
  • Wynn Resorts (WYNN) – The casino co. has partnered with the European-based BetBull Limited, a digital sports betting operator, to grow in the emerging US market for sports betting. (Newswires)

NASDAQ

  • Align Technology (ALGN) – The orthodontics co. is expanding its recently launched interactive brand experience programme into eight new US locations. (Newswires)
  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – The tech giant is partnering up with Orange SA (ORAN FP) to implement a new, 6,600km Dunant submarine cable connecting the US with France, where fibre-pairs will have a capacity of more than 30Tbp/s; this will be the first new submarine cable in more than 15 years. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The online retailer has had over 1000 data centre locations revealed by Wikileaks. Elsewhere, the co. has replaced Alibaba (BABA) in Stifel’s Select List, citing near-term optimism for Amazon and a poor China macro environment for Alibaba. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – It has been revealed that a business unit of the social media co., named Building 8, has been working to build the world’s first brain-computer interfaces, giving computer-like functionality in people’s heads. Elsewhere, the co. is rolling out 3D photos in its News Feed for users to experiment with. (Newswires)
  • Illumina (ILMN) – The biotech co. has had its price target raised to USD 350 from USD 330 at Deutsche Bank, citing bias for upside in the estimates and positive newsflow in clinical markets. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The automaker has said that orders for cars placed by October 15th will be eligible for a full federal tax credit of USD 7,500 and delivery by year-end. Elsewhere, the co.’s subsidiary SolarCity has settled a case with the state of Oregon after it was accused of inflating product prices to qualify for higher state tax credits; it will pay Oregon USD 13mln. Also, its US sales are gaining on BMW (BMW GY) and other luxury car makers including Lexus, Mercedes-Benz, Audi. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Athenahealth (ATHN) – The healthcare-focused network services provider has approached suitors which it previously rejected as stronger offers have failed to materialise; this is part of the co.’s ongoing pressure from activist investor Paul Singer’s Elliot Management to sell itself. (NY Post)
  • Blackstone (BX) – The private equity firm is reportedly close to completing a GBP 800mln purchase of the UK-based live events complex, the NEC Group. (Sky News)
  • Fitbit (FIT) – The co. gained momentum pre-market after Wedbush turned bullish over the co.’s expansion into the MedTech market. (Newswires)
  • GeiGene (BGNE) – The pharma co. has updated Phase 1 data results from its Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia treating BTK inhibitor zanubrutinib, where it now has stronger supporting data for its NDA. (Newswires)
  • Ni Source (NI) - Columbia Gas, an affiliate of the co. was blamed for a deadly explosion in Massachusetts; the National Transportation Safety board said the co. did not require repair teams to reapply sensors while conducting works on the gas pipelines. (Newswires)
  • Sears (SHLD) – The retailer is in talks with banks who are advising it to liquidate its assets rather than rely on bankruptcy protection in an effort to save an “American legend”. (WSJ)
  • Tencent (TCEHY) – The Chinese tech co.’s subsidiary, Tencent Music, has postponed its IPO till at least November, citing the recent global market selloff. Elsewhere, the co. has approached Apple (AAPL) to inform them that hackers have broken into customer accounts using stolen Apple IDs to steal unknown amounts of cash. (WSJ, Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

Upgrades

  • CANADIAN PACIFIC (CP) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT STIFEL
  • COSTCO (COST) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT NORTHCOAST
  • EASTMAN CHEMICAL (EMN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JPMORGAN
  • ENSCO (ESV) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SOCIETE GENERALE
  • ENSCO (ESV) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN
  • FITBIT (FIT) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT WEDBUSH
  • JETBLUE (JBLU) UPGRADED TO PEER PERFORM FROM UNDERPERFORM AT WOLFE RESEARCH

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 12th October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • USD/TRY below 6 but choppy awaiting Pastor Brunson’s Constitutional Court appeal verdict
  • Cable also volatile ahead of next week’s key Brexit summit, with big issues still to be resolved
  • European equites tentative ahead of key US bank earnings
  • Looking ahead, other highlights include, US Import/Export Prices, Uni. of Michigan, Fed’s Evans, Bostic and ECB’s Draghi

ASIA

Asian equities traded mixed as the bourses attempted to mount a recovery following the downbeat lead from Wall St. where the region was pressured by energy names, closely followed by the financial sector which entered correction territory. The Dow eroded over 500 points, bringing the two-day loss to over 1,300 points, while S&P notched a six-day losing streak and closed below its 200 DMA. ASX 200 (+0.2%) recuperated initial losses as the commodity names recovered, while Nikkei 225 (+0.46%) traded off lows as the Japanese currency showed some mild weakness. Elsewhere, China traded mixed with the Hang Seng (+2.1%) buoyed by industrial and finance names while Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) was pressured by oil names following the recent decline in the complex.

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9120 (Prev. 6.9098) (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 160bln vs. net drain CNY 230bln in the week of September 24th

China Trade Balance USD (Sep) 31.69B vs. Exp. 19.4B (Prev. 27.91B, Rev. 27.89B) (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US is committed to fair trading agreement with China, fair and reciprocal trade deals. (Newswires)

China customs said the impact from US trade friction is "controllable” and added that foreign trade growth may slow on year in Q4. (Newswires)

China receives around USD 13.2bln in orders for sale of USD denominated 5, 10 and 30yr bonds. (Newswires)

Japanese Economy Minister Motegi said they will continue to watch developments in global economy including trade policy. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

German Finance Minister Scholz says Italian politicians said they will respect EU rules, adding that one should take that at face value. Italy should be "careful" given its refinancing needs. (Newswires)

ECB's Draghi reiterates that Euro area economy is experiencing a broad based expansion, with underlying inflation expected to pick up towards the year end and increase gradually. (Newswires)

An official close to Brexit talks said that May never brings the cabinet together to tell them what is going on, feels like the deal is practically done. She also said Brexit backstop talks are likely to continue until November. (Newswires) BBC's Laura Kuenssberg reported that no real progress was made at the cabinet meeting and no decisions have been made but discussions will continue. (Newswires)

There were reports that UK PM May was to make a public statement saying the UK will not agree to being permanently being trapped in a customs union; this has since been reported as false by UK PM May’s office. UK PM May’s Spokesperson then  said the PM will never agree to a Brexit backstop plan that will trap Britain in a customs union permanently, the backstop must be temporary. (Newswires)

At least three Eurosceptic Cabinet ministers are said to be considering quitting over the latest concession, which appears to contradict Mrs May’s promise earlier this year that the backstop would expire “at the very latest by the end of December 2021”. (The Telegraph)

UK Conservative Commons leader Andrea Leadsom is preparing to resign if Theresa May compromises any further on her Brexit plans, according to The Independent. (The Independent)

Mexican Government said it will take necessary actions to protect exporters in the short term, adding it will use all mechanisms available under NAFTA and WTO to be totally excluded from Canada's safeguards. There were also reports that Mexico are said to plan to review Canada steel tariffs as a potential violation of NAFTA (Newswires)

US President Trump is mulling candidates who could replace Attorney General Sessions (WSJ)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says that he instructed PBOC Governor Yi Gang that any trade discussions between the US and China must involve talks on currency. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are in the green, albeit off best levels (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%) after bouncing back from yesterday’s global downturn; the SMI is out in front up by just under 1%, spurred on by the resolution of a Novartis (+1.7%) patent dispute.

Major sectors are all up, with consumer discretionary leading by just over 1% as well as financials and IT by over 0.6% indicating that market confidence is returning; further emphasised by the dip in gold.

In terms of individual equities there is continued support for Dialog Semiconductor (+4.3%) following yesterday’s news of a deal with Apple. Man Group is up by 3% following quarterly net inflows of USD 0.4bln. An upgrade to outperform at Credit Suisse for Zalando sees them up by 3.5%. Victrex are down 3.5% after being downgraded to underweight at Morgan Stanley.

FX

DXY - Very dull and rangy trade, with Usd/major pairings mostly going through the motions approaching the end of a relatively volatile week. Consequently, the index is straddling 95.000 and anchored near the lows in wake of softer than forecast US PPI and CPI reports, a drift back from multi-year peaks in Treasury yields, and yet more Fed critique from President Trump about the pace of policy normalisation.

GBP/TRY - Not necessarily the biggest outright movers, but certainly among the most choppy as Cable rallied to marginally fresh wtd highs just shy of 1.3260 on latest positive Brexit deal vibes (ostensibly) before hitting a brick wall and reversing sharply towards 1.3200. The swift price action and retreat may also be option related given mega expiry interest between 1.3235-50 (1.5 bn) for Monday when some have speculated that an agreement between the UK and EU could be reached, although this appears to be very doubtful with a few big issues still unresolved. Similarly, the Lira rebounded further through 6.0000 vs the Usd, and all the way to circa 5.8400 at one stage on a wave of expectation that the Turkish court will grant the release of US Pastor Brunson (latest appeal hearing now underway), but then retreated abruptly to around 5.9835 alongside a broader downturn in domestic stocks and bonds awaiting the verdict.

CAD/NZD/AUD/EUR/CHF/JPY - All narrowly mixed against the Greenback, with the Loonie firming up within a 1.3000-40 range and possibly getting drawn to a hefty 1 bn option expiry at the big figure. The Kiwi and Aud are both sitting a tad more comfortably above round numbers at 0.6500 and 0.7100 respectively, but still hampered by ongoing US-China trade strains that will hardly be helped by Chinese data overnight showing a bulging surplus and fresh record vs the US. The single currency remains elevated and has pivoted 1.1600 with some impetus via the Eur/Jpy cross following reports of leverage account short covering and a squeeze through 130.00 to nearly 130.50 at one stage. However, Eur/Usd may also be feeling the gravitation pull of option expiries with 1.3 bn running off from 1.1590-1.1600, ahead of 1 bn at 1.1550. The Franc is also restrained and tethered to 0.9900, while Usd/Jpy is close to the middle of 112.00-50 parameters.

SEK/NOK - The Scandi crowns continue to strengthen and outperform on Swedish and Norwegian inflation reports that will keep both the Norges Bank and Riksbank firmly on course to hike rates well before the ECB (and in the case of the latter that means further after September’s 25 bp tightening). Eur/Sek has now breached previous October lows to trade down at 10.3625 and Eur/Nok is back under 9.5000.

COMMODITIES

Gold has dropped by 0.2% today following a reduction in the risk sentiment as markets calm and traders begin to move out of the safe havens. The yellow metal is currently at just under USD 1220/oz, although this is still close to a 10 week high. Copper prices have benefited from data showing that China has imported a near record amount last month; similarly, iron ore prices to their highest levels in 4 months from high Chinese imports. Steel prices rose, resulting in the best week since mid-August as Tangshan steel mill output is halved from October 11th-18th.

WTI and Brent are both up for the day albeit of best levels with WTI under USD 71.50/bbl and USD 80.50/bbl; With the weekly change at -4% for both WTI and Brent. In terms of energy commentary, the IEA notes that global spare oil capacity is down to 2% of global demand, additionally noting that further falls are likely. Additionally, global oil supply is rapidly increasing, with production up by 2.6mln bpd compared to a year ago. With the weekly change at -4% for both WTI and Brent.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have pared losses and relatively recovered well from a slightly deeper dip through 158.00 to 157.95 and recently printed a new Eurex high at 158.28 (-7 ticks vs -40 ticks at worst), but remain hostage to an extent to BTPs that are still above 120.00, albeit off 120.46 peaks. Hence, the rebound in Gilts is even more impressive as the 10 year debt future erased all of its losses and almost climbed the same margin above parity to 120.21 (+17 ticks vs -1/4 point soon after Liffe resumed) before running out of steam. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are back in bear-steepening mode after acknowledging rather than really taking on board the magnitude of Wall Street’s cumulative collapse on Wednesday and Thursday, or for that matter benign inflation inputs via PPI and CPI, as Fed rhetoric does not suggest any deviation from 2018 guidance and a final hike in December, unless Q4 data is dire of course.

  • Adding that big issues remain in focus ahead of next weeks EU summit.

subject: FX Morning Colour: Dollar remains dour, but Pound and Lira lively
content:
DXY

Very dull and rangy trade, with Usd/major pairings mostly going through the motions approaching the end of a relatively volatile week. Consequently, the index is straddling 95.000 and anchored near the lows in wake of softer than forecast US PPI and CPI reports, a drift back from multi-year peaks in Treasury yields, and yet more Fed critique from President Trump about the pace of policy normalisation.

GBP/TRY

Not necessarily the biggest outright movers, but certainly among the most choppy as Cable rallied to marginally fresh wtd highs just shy of 1.3260 on latest positive Brexit deal vibes (ostensibly) before hitting a brick wall and reversing sharply towards 1.3200. The swift price action and retreat may also be option related given mega expiry interest between 1.3235-50 (1.5 bn) for Monday when some have speculated that an agreement between the UK and EU could be reached, although this appears to be very doubtful with a few big issues still unresolved. Similarly, the Lira rebounded further through 6.0000 vs the Usd, and all the way to circa 5.8400 at one stage on a wave of expectation that the Turkish court will grant the release of US Pastor Brunson (latest appeal hearing now underway), but then retreated abruptly to around 5.9835 alongside a broader downturn in domestic stocks and bonds awaiting the verdict.

CAD/NZD/AUD/EUR/CHF/JPY

All narrowly mixed against the Greenback, with the Loonie firming up within a 1.3000-40 range and possibly getting drawn to a hefty 1 bn option expiry at the big figure. The Kiwi and Aud are both sitting a tad more comfortably above round numbers at 0.6500 and 0.7100 respectively, but still hampered by ongoing US-China trade strains that will hardly be helped by Chinese data overnight showing a bulging surplus and fresh record vs the US. The single currency remains elevated and has pivoted 1.1600 with some impetus via the Eur/Jpy cross following reports of leverage account short covering and a squeeze through 130.00 to nearly 130.50 at one stage. However, Eur/Usd may also be feeling the gravitation pull of option expiries with 1.3 bn running off from 1.1590-1.1600, ahead of 1 bn at 1.1550. The Franc is also restrained and tethered to 0.9900, while Usd/Jpy is close to the middle of 112.00-50 parameters.

SEK/NOK

The Scandi crowns continue to strengthen and outperform on Swedish and Norwegian inflation reports that will keep both the Norges Bank and Riksbank firmly on course to hike rates well before the ECB (and in the case of the latter that means further after September’s 25 bp tightening). Eur/Sek has now breached previous October lows to trade down at 10.3625 and Eur/Nok is back under 9.5000.

subject: Bunds: reversing to circa 158.00 as risk assets and BTPs regroup
content: Not quite all change, but another swing in sentiment following relatively resilient trade across Asia-Pacific bourses given the 2nd hefty sell-off on Wall Street yesterday. Hence, the 10 year German bond started 19 ticks below Thursday’s 158.35 Eurex close and after a fleeting uptick to 158.18 has steadily slipped back to test big figure support at 157.97, with added pressure coming via Italian debt that has been mostly on the front foot in early Friday trade – 10 year BTP currently near the top of a 120.40-119.67 range. Ahead, Eurozone ip data and ECB commentary courtesy Lautenschlager, President Draghi and Coeure. Back to Bunds, 157.96 could provide some support on a chart basis ahead of 157.91-85 and then 157.74-72.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 12th October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equities traded mixed as the bourses attempted to mount a recovery following the downbeat lead from Wall St.
  • BBC's Laura Kuenssberg reported that no real progress was made at yesterday’s cabinet meeting, but discussions will continue
  • Turkish officials expect the court to release Pastor Brunson on Friday, after NBC reported a secret agreement has been brokered to release the Pastor
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German CPI (F), IEA Monthly Oil Market Report, US Import/Export Prices, Uni. of Michigan, ECB’s Lautenschlaeger, Fed’s Evans, Bostic and ECB’s Draghi

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded mixed as the bourses attempted to mount a recovery following the downbeat lead from Wall St. where the region was pressured by energy names, closely followed by the financial sector which entered correction territory. The Dow eroded over 500 points, bringing the two-day loss to over 1,300 points, while S&P notched a six-day losing streak and closed below its 200 DMA. ASX 200 (+0.1%) recuperated initial losses as the commodity names recovered, while Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) traded off lows as the Japanese currency showed some mild weakness. Elsewhere, China traded mixed with the Hang Seng (+0.8%) buoyed by industrial and finance names while Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) was pressured by oil names following the recent decline in the complex.

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9120 (Prev. 6.9098) (Newswires)
PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 160bln vs. net drain CNY 230bln in the week of September 24th

China Trade Balance USD (Sep) 31.69B vs. Exp. 19.4B (Prev. 27.91B, Rev. 27.89B) (Newswires)
China Trade Surplus with US (Sep) (USD) 34.13B (Prev. 31.05B) (A record high)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US is committed to fair trading agreement with China, fair and reciprocal trade deals. (Newswires)

China customs said the impact from US trade friction is "controllable” and added that foreign trade growth may slow on year in Q4. (Newswires)

China will not be named currency manipulator in Treasury's Semi-annual Currency Report next week. (Politico)

China receives around USD 13.2bln in orders for sale of USD denominated 5, 10 and 30yr bonds. (Newswires)

Japanese Economy Minister Motegi said they will continue to watch developments in global economy including trade policy. (Newswires)

UK

UK PM May briefed her inner cabinet on Thursday evening that a historic Brexit deal is close. An official close to Brexit talks said that May never brings the cabinet together to tell them what is going on, feels like the deal is practically done. She also said Brexit backstop talks are likely to continue until November. (Newswires) BBC's Laura Kuenssberg reported that no real progress was made at the cabinet meeting and no decisions have been made but discussions will continue. (Newswires)

Further reports suggested that UK PM May is facing the threat of Cabinet resignations after she accepted EU demands that there will be no time limit on her controversial Brexit backstop plan. At least three eurosceptic Cabinet ministers are said to be considering quitting over the latest concession, which appears to contradict Mrs May’s promise earlier this year that the backstop would expire “at the very latest by the end of December 2021”. (The Telegraph)

The BBC understands UK Trade Secretary Liam Fox, Environmental Secretary Michael Gove and Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab expressed concern about potential compromises with the EU over Brexit. (BBC)

A top DUP MP told Sky News that Conservatives may have to change leader to "heal wounds" with the DUP and ensure its confidence and supply agreement "stays in place", while DUP leader said PM May could not in good conscience recommend a deal which places a trade barrier within the UK. (Newswires)


EU

ECB won't come to Italy's rescue if government and banks run out of cash unless EU bailout in place, ECB Sources. (Newswires)

Italy's Senate voted to push balanced budget goal beyond 2021, approves budget deficit target. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the greenback was little changed and pivoted on either side of 95.00, while GBP/USD moved sideways below 1.3250 and EUR/USD traded just above 1.1600 as the EUR/JPY pair tested 130.40 to the upside amid safe-haven outflow, subsequently pushing USD/JPY further above the 112.00 level. Elsewhere, AUD shrugged off worse-than-expected home loans data, which was followed by a mixed RBA financial stability review.

RBA Financial Stability Review noted the Australian economy is improving but housing market has slowed and added that trade tensions and slowdown in China could trigger global economic downturn. (Newswires)

Turkish officials expect the court to release Pastor Brunson on Friday, after NBC reported a secret agreement has been brokered to release Pastor Brunson, while the US State Department said it is not aware of any deal to secure the release of US Pastor Brunson. (Newswires)

Brazilian presidential candidate Haddad wants to use 10% of Brazil's FX reserves to finance wind and solar energy projects in the North-East. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Turkish Central Bank Governor said the central bank will continue to use all available instruments in pursuit of price stability objectives and deterioration in pricing behaviour poses upside risk on inflation outlook despite domestic demand conditions. (Newswires)

ECB's Weidmann (Hawk) said lower growth rates in worlds economy are more a normalisation than a consequence of trade friction. (Newswires)

Fed's George (Non-voter, Hawk) says gradual rate hikes needed, pace and extent of hikes are a key part of the FOMC's deliberations; risks to US economy are balanced but inflation could rise over the next couple of years. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Treasury Department is said to have sought meetings with South Korean banks regarding North Korea's sanctions. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed as WTI and Brent nursed some losses with the former moving north of USD 71.50/bbl while the latter reclaimed USD 81/bbl to the upside as sentiment around the market took a turn for the better. Elsewhere, metals were mostly lower as gold unwound some risk premium, albeit still near two-month highs and copper bounced off lows seen during the mass sell-off.

US Gulf of Mexico oil producers shut in 40% of oil output ahead of hurricane Michael (prev. 42%), shut in 29% natural gas output (prev. 32%). There were sperate reports of US oil firms restoring operations in Gulf of Mexico. NHC said Tropical Storm Michael is losing Tropical characteristics (Newswires)

Ecuador Oil Minister said he expects crude output of 540k BPD in 2018 and 590k BPD in 2019; he supports the crude output hike by OPEC in December meeting prices are reasonable around USD 70-80/bbl.

US

Treasuries ended Thursday session in positive territory as equities extended their rout and CPI numbers missed expectations. The yield curve bull-flattened with short dated yields lower by c.4bps and long dated yields down by c.9bps at settlement. 2s30 5s30s were narrower by c.3bps.The US Treasury sold USD 15bln of 30-year bonds, stopping through by 0.9bps at a high yield of 3.344%. Demand for the auction was strong as indicated by the bid-to-cover which stood above recent averages. Directs were awarded the biggest share since April, indirects also took the largest portion since January whilst dealers were left with the smallest share since January.  * US T-note futures (Z8) settle 20+ ticks higher at 118-12+.

US President Trump said the Fed is out of control, is far too stringent and making a mistake. (Newswires)

Mexican Government said it will take necessary actions to protect exporters in the short term, adding it will use all mechanisms available under NAFTA and WTO to be totally excluded from Canada's safeguards. There were also reports that Mexico are said to plan to review Canada steel tariffs as a potential violation of NAFTA (Newswires)

US President Trump is mulling candidates who could replace Attorney General Sessions (WSJ)

US officials were told by Turkey that they have video and audio proof that journalist Khashoggi was killed in Saudi consulate, while US Senators pushed vote to block Saudi arms sale following the journalist disappearance. (Newswires)
